As an extension of latent class analysis (LCA), LTA identifies latent classes at each time point and estimates the probabilities of individuals transitioning between these classes across multiple time points. This approach allows researchers to examine patterns of change in categorical latent variables, such as behavioral or psychological states, and to assess how covariates may influence these transitions."}]},{"type":"element","tag":"p","props":{},"children":[{"type":"text","value":"In LTA, individuals are assumed to belong to latent classes that represent unobserved subgroups within the population. By modeling the probabilities of transitioning from one latent class to another over time, LTA captures both the stability and change in these unobserved states. This provides insights into the dynamics of latent constructs, such as how certain behaviors may emerge, persist, or dissipate over time."}]},{"type":"element","tag":"p","props":{},"children":[{"type":"text","value":"LTA is particularly useful where understanding the progression of categorical states is essential.
